title-group.article-title: Shortened carbon nanotubes and their influence on the electrical properties of polymer nanocomposites

contrib-group.aff: 1Advanced Composite Training and Development Centre, Glyndŵr University, Airbus site, CH5 3US Hawarden, UK
2School of Mechanical and Aeronautical Engineering, Glyndŵr University, Mold Road, LL11 2AW Wrexham, UK
3School of Engineering and Materials Science, University of London, Mile End Road, E1 4NS London, UK
4Eindhoven Polymer Laboratories, Eindhoven University of Technology, 5600 MB Eindhoven, The Netherlands

author-notes.corresp: Fawad Inam, Advanced Composite Training and Development Centre, Glyndŵr University, Mold Road, LL11 2AW Wrexham, UK Email: f.inam@glyndwr.ac.uk

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Multi-wall carbon nanotubes of medium length (mCNTs) were aggressively tip-ultrasonicated to produce shortened and damaged carbon nanotubes (xCNTs). High-resolution electron microscopic analysis was performed to measure the dimensions of carbon nanotubes (CNTs). Thermo-gravimetric analysis and Raman spectroscopy were used to evaluate the damage in the sonicated CNTs. Short CNTs (sCNTs), in their pristine form (undamaged), were used for comparison with sonicated xCNTs. Good dispersion was achieved when CNTs were bath-ultrasonicated in epoxy resin. The electrical conductivities were measured for cured CNT/epoxy nanocomposites. Compared to shorter CNTs (xCNT and sCNT), mCNT lowered the percolation threshold of CNT/epoxy nanocomposites for electrical conductivity. While ultrasonically shortened xCNTs did give a percolation threshold similar to that of sCNT/epoxy nanocomposites, lower ultimate electrical conductivities were obtained for nanocomposites based on xCNTs due to the presence of structural defects.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Since the discovery of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) in early 1990s,1 numerous papers have been focusing on the mechanical2–4 and electrical2,5–12 properties of polymer/CNT nanocomposites.13 Compared to other nanocomposite systems, these materials displayed a supreme combination of excellent mechanical, electrical, and electronic properties. In particular, the value of the electrical percolation threshold for insulator–conductive filler composites can be significantly reduced by increasing the aspect ratio of the conductive filler and numerous research studies have been devoted to this effect.5–8 A three-dimensional network of conductive filler is required to provide a conductive path (percolation) throughout a composite material. The percolation threshold is characterized by a sharp reduction in electrical resistance.14 The percolation threshold of CNTs in polymers is sensitive to the degree of contacts, aspect ratio of CNTs, interactions between CNTs,12 operating temperature,9,10 state of the applied stress,2,10 and alignment of CNTs in the polymer nanocomposites.11 Percolation theory is frequently applied to explain the electrical percolation behavior of an insulating polymer filled with a conductive filler like CNTs. The percolation threshold for a three-dimensional percolating system can be theoretically described by the following (Equation (1)) scaling law:15

where σDC is the DC electrical conductivity of the nanocomposite, σo the electrical conductivity of CNTs, φ the volume fraction of the filler, φc the volume fraction of the percolation threshold, and t the critical exponent. However, the selection of the value for t is an issue.16–18 Celzard et al.5 developed the ‘exclude volume theory’ for predicting the percolation threshold of a high aspect ratio rod-shaped filler system. This analytical model does not involve the careful selection of the critical exponent. The theory has been extensively used to describe various polymer micro- and nanocomposites.19–21 Particularly for randomly oriented CNTs/epoxy nanocomposites, the percolation threshold range can be calculated using modified exclude volume theory (Equation (2)) for isotropic materials:5 (2) where φc is the volume% of the percolation threshold, <Ve> the exclude volume of CNT/epoxy nanocomposite, and <V> the volume of CNTs. <Ve> and <V> can be calculated by:

where W and L are the diameter and length of the CNTs, respectively. Equation (3) is valid for randomly oriented capped CNTs. Recently, Bauhofer and Kovacs13 presented a comprehensive review and analysis of electrical percolation and conductivities in carbon nanotube/polymer nanocomposites. Although their paper reports on the effect of CNT length on electrical properties of conductive polymer composites,13 no comments were made on the effect of shortened/damaged CNTs on the electrical conductivity of polymer/CNT nanocomposites.

Long CNTs form entangled agglomerates that are difficult to disperse.22 Such agglomerates increase the viscosity of epoxy and high shear rates are required for near-complete dispersal of those aggregates.23 In terms of physical properties, short CNTs provide the same network attributes as long ones at modestly higher concentrations, but at a significantly lower network yield stress, which implies better processability.24 To date, according to our knowledge, this article is the first to analyze the effect of shortening of CNTs on the electrical properties of CNT/epoxy nanocomposites. We also demonstrate that shortened CNTs can be produced using physical methods instead of chemical treatments. In this study, high-power (750 W) tip-ultrasonication isused for shortening CNTs as longer times of ultrasonication introduce too many defects, leading to a toosevere reduction in CNT lengths.25,26 However, ultrasonication will also open the ends of CNTs and can induce damage in the graphene structure, leading to the formation of amorphous carbon.27,28 Thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA), Raman spectroscopy, and high-resolution electron microscopy (HR-TEM) were used to evaluate the damage in the shortened CNTs. Particularly, Raman spectroscopy is a good tool for the quantification of crystallinity in CNTs.29 In Raman spectroscopy of CNTs, the peak at ∼100–400 cm–1 corresponds to a Radial Breathing Mode, which is more relevant for single-wall CNTs.29 The peak at ∼1320–1350 cm–1 corresponds to a disorder-induced phonon mode (D band) in multi-walled CNTs (MWNTs). The peak at ∼1525–1575 cm–1 can be assigned to the G band of MWNTs, which is produced by tangential stretching of sp2 bonded carbon atoms in a two-dimensional hexagonal lattice.29–31 The D band is a signature for defects and provides a measure of the structural disorder produced by amorphous carbon and any defects.29 Peak intensities of D and G bands are ID and IG, respectively. According to Tuinstra and Koenig,32 an increase in ID/IG corresponds to an increase in the amount of ‘unorganized’ carbon and/or decrease in the mean crystal size.29 ID/IG > 2 indicates a highly damaged form of carbon.32 There is a considerable amount of experimental evidence showing that any interfacial interaction with a polymer matrix31 and sidewall derivatization33 of CNTs significantly increases ID/IG. Moreover, during graphitization, the ID becomes smaller than IG, which indicates a more perfect graphene structure.34 Therefore, in this study, we used the ID/IG ratio supported by high-resolution transmission electron microscopic analysis to study the degradation of CNTs.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
The epoxy matrix used in this study consists of an Araldite LY 564 (Huntsman LLC) liquid epoxy resin with an anhydride hardener (Lindride 32, supplied by Lindau Chemical Inc.). The CNTs used in this study were kindly supplied by Nanocyl S.A., Belgium (Table 1). They were synthesized by the catalytic chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method, having an average outer diameter of 10 nm (about 10 graphitic shells) and a carbon purity >95%. Table 1.
CNTs supplied by Nanocyl S.A., Belgium
Commercial grade Abbreviation Length (µm, as per supplier)
NC-3100 mCNTs 0.1–10
NC-3150 sCNTs <1

sec.title: Ultrasonication
sec.p: To produce shortened CNTs, medium long CNTs (grade NC-3100) were tip-sonicated for 6 and 12 min in distilled water using Z511463 Sigma–Aldrich ultrasonic processors (750 W). The supernatant was collected, which is referred as damaged carbon nanotubes (xCNTs) (tip-sonication time: 12 min) in this article. Ultrasonication is a good technique for dispersing the highly entangled or aggregated CNTs.25,35 Different compositions of CNT/epoxy dispersions (0.05 wt%, 0.1 wt%, 0.25 wt%, 0.5 wt%, 0.625 wt%, 0.75 wt%, 0.8 wt%, 1 wt%, and 2 wt%) were aggressively hand-mixed for 5 min and then homogenized using a high-power bath ultrasonication (Decon Ultrasonics Ltd, FS Minor) for 5 h. This method is highly effective for lower concentrations (<1 vol.%) of CNTs and results in a good level of dispersion.22,36 As per supplier, hardener (85 parts) was added with epoxy (100 parts). After degassing (at 40°C/30 mm Hg) the suspension for 30 min in a vacuum oven, CNT/epoxy nanocomposites were cured in an open polytetrafluoroethylene mold. The resin was cured at 125°C (heating rate: 1°C/min) for an hour and cooled slowly in the oven to avoid thermally induced matrix cracking. After curing, the nanocomposites were allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The same method was used to prepare pure epoxy for comparison.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: Field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, FEI Inspect F, 10 kV) was used to take the images of the collected CNTs. Lengths of CNTs were measured with the aid of computer software UTHSCSA ImageTool, v.3.0. At least 5000 CNTs were analyzed for studying the lengths and representative images are presented in this article. This approach has been widely used to measure CNT dimensions.7,14,37 High-resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HR-TEM) was carried on a JEOL 2010 (200 kV) to study the structures and diameters of CNTs before and after tip-sonication. HR-TEM was also used to analyse the lengths of CNTs as well. The Raman spectra for CNTs were obtained on a Renishaw Raman Imaging Microscope System. Sample masses ranged from 25 to 30 mg. Raman spectra were excited with a 488 nm Ar+ laser line at a power of 35 mW. Spectra were detected with an imaging photomultiplier (1024 × 1024) with 5 cm−1 resolution. Typical collection times were 5 min. At least 10 observations were made to determine the ratios of the intensities of the D and G bands.

Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a TA Instruments SDT Q600 TGA thermogravimetric analyzer. CNTs were analyzed in platinum pans at a heating rate of 30°C/min to 1000°C in air flowing at 180 mL/min. Sample masses ranged from 30 to 40 mg. The oxidation temperatures were measured using the intersection point of extrapolated lines. The electrical properties of the CNT/epoxy nanocomposites were characterized by a two-point method17,38 using a highly sensitive digital micro-ohmmeter (Keithley 580). At least five samples were analysed for electrical conductivity measurements. Silver paste was applied on two ends of the CNT/epoxy samples (4×4×3 mm3) to insure good electrical contact between the sample and two electrodes. The electrical resistivity was measured at room temperature (25°C). For qualitative assessment of dispersion, the fracture surfaces of the nanocomposites were coated with a thin layer of gold and transferred to FE-SEM for examination.

sec.title: Characterization of CNTs
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows the CNTs used to make epoxy-based nanocomposites in which the lengths of pristine and ultrasonicated CNTs can be compared. At least 10 SEM images (≥5000 CNTs) were analyzed and the representative images are presented in Figure 1. Different areas were observed to compare the lengths of CNTs and the representative ones are shown in Figure 1. CNTs appear to be shortened in their lengths after severe tip-sonication. HR-TEM analysis revealed no change in the diameters of CNTs after tip-sonication. Figure 2 shows the lengths of CNTs before and after tip-sonication. This approach can be used to study the effect of dimensions and damage on the final properties of the CNT nanocomposites. Different ultrasonication times produced CNTs of different lengths, that is, 6 min of ultrasonication produced xCNTs having average length ∼1267 nm, whereas 12 min of ultrasonication produced xCNTs having average length ∼729 nm (Figure 2). A further optimization of the variables (Figure 2(c) and (d)) of tip-sonication can produce CNTs of desired lengths, which is the subject of future research. It should be noted that short CNTs (sCNTs) (Figure 2(b)) and xCNTs after 12 min of sonication (Figure 2(d)) are approximately having similar length distributions while their mean lengths are also the same. From Figure 1, it is not possible to evaluate possible structural defects in the CNTs. However, HR-TEM revealed details of the damage caused by tip-sonication (Figure 3). Shortened and thinned CNTs with damaged ends were observed after severe tip-sonication. HR-TEM is a good technique to qualitatively visualize such damage; however, it is not possible to evaluate the real extent of such damage. Figure 1.
FE-SEM images of CNTs: (a) mCNTs; (b) sCNTs; (c) shortened CNTs after 6 min of tip-sonication (xxCNTs); and (d) shortened CNTs after 12 min of tip-sonication (xCNTs). Figure 2.
Dimensional analysis of CNTs: (a) mCNTs; (b) sCNTs; (c) shortened CNTs after 6 min of tip-sonication (xxCNTs); and (d) shortened CNTs after 12 min of tip-sonication (xCNTs). Figure 3.
HR-TEM images of CNTs: (a) mCNTs; and (b) shortened CNTs (xCNTs) after tip-sonication.

With the aid of TGA (Figure 4) and Raman spectroscopy (Figure 5), a thorough quantitative assessment of CNT damage was performed. Local defects in CNT walls and open-ended CNTs lead to a lower oxidation temperature,22 for which TGA was carried out (Figure 4). The mCNTs possessed the highest oxidation temperature, that is, 510°C compared to shorter CNTs (sCNTs and xCNTs). Because of the damage caused by prior tip-sonication, xCNTs showed the lowest oxidation temperature, that is, 445°C. On the other hand, sCNTs having similar dimension as xCNTs, showed a higher oxidation temperature (487°C) because of fewer structural defects (Figure 4). Raman spectroscopic analysis results of different CNTs along with the intensity ratios of the D and G bands are shown in Figure 5. The D and G peaks of the MWNTs were sharply observed at 1336 and 1557 cm−1, respectively. No peak shift was observed for xCNT after tip-sonication. However, an increase in ID/IG ratio (∼2.5) corresponds to a major disorder in the structure of CNT after severe tip-sonication. The mCNTs and sCNTs were well preserved in all the nanocomposites as the ID/IG ratios are ∼1.1 (Figure 5). Figure 4.
TGA of the different types of CNTs. Figure 5.
Raman spectroscopic analysis results of different types of CNTs.

sec.title: CNT/epoxy nanocomposites
sec.p:
Electron microscopy revealed that all CNTs were well dispersed in the epoxy matrix (Figure 6). In CNT/polymer nanocomposites, non-entangled straight CNTs have shown to give conductivities up to 50 times higher than those based on highly entangled CNTs from CVD based on industrial mass production processes.17 However, the fracture surface of the CNT/epoxy nanocomposites revealed that some CNT agglomerates were still present. CNTs were mostly buried inside the epoxy matrix and some of the CNTs appeared to be pulled out from the polymer matrix. From TGA and Raman spectroscopy (ratio of D and G peak intensities) data, it is clear that xCNTs possess more chemical and structural damage compared to pristine mCNTs. However, as the lengths of xCNTs and sCNTs are quite similar (Figure 2(b) and (d)), a direct comparison between xCNTs and sCNTs can be made, allowing for a comparison of the effect of xCNT damage on the electrical properties of epoxy-based nanocomposites. The percolation thresholds and electrical conductivities for the different nanocomposites are shown in Figure 7. Figure 6.
CNT/epoxy nanocomposites with 1.4 vol.% (2 wt%) CNTs: (a) mCNTs; and (b) shortened CNTs (xCNTs). Figure 7.
Electrical conductivity values of various CNT/epoxy nanocomposites.

The lengths of the CNTs clearly affect the percolation thresholds of their respective nanocomposites.12,39 Longer CNTs form an entangled percolating network more efficiently compared to sCNTs.12,39 Figure 8 shows experimentally observed and theoretically predicted percolation thresholds for various CNT/epoxy nanocomposites. To date, the lowest percolation threshold measured (using Equation (1)) for CNTs in epoxy is 0.0021 wt% (0.0015 vol.%).7 This is due to the electrostatic stabilization of CNTs by an electrical field that leads to a significant lowering of the percolation threshold.7 The differences between the experimentally observed and theoretically predicted values are due to differences in the types, length distributions, and qualities of CNTs and dispersion procedures. Only percolation thresholds of aligned CNT/epoxy nanocomposites match with their theoretically predicted values (Figure 8). When CNTs are not oriented, Gojny et al.40 reported a significantly higher percolation threshold (0.03 wt%, 0.02 vol.%). However, this percolation threshold14 was achieved with significantly longer CNTs (aspect ratio: ∼1000) than those used in this study. Compared to these reports,7,14 the CNTs used in this study have much lower aspect ratios, namely, mCNT: 157 and sCNT: 71. Figure 8.
Percolation thresholds for various CNT/epoxy nanocomposites. Notes: Shaded area is the percolation threshold range predicted by excluded volume theory5 for W = 10 nm (Equations (2)–(4)). (•) represents this study, (▴) other researchers 7,14,16–18,40–44, and (†) nanocomposites based on aligned CNTs with the aid of an electric field.

mCNT/epoxy nanocomposites possess a very low percolation threshold (0.07 vol.%) compared to sCNT/epoxy (0.44 vol.%) and xCNT/epoxy (0.44 vol.%) nanocomposites (Figures 7 and Figures 8). To date, the percolation thresholds observed for sCNT/epoxy and xCNT/epoxy are the lowest for CNTs having aspect ratio values <100. These percolation thresholds may be further improved by combining short CNTs with some long CNTs, as predicted by Schoot et al.12,39 Mixtures of short and long CNTs may lead to an optimal combination of electrical properties and processability and this will be the subject of our future research. Nodifferences in percolation threshold were observed for sCNT/epoxy and xCNT/epoxy nanocomposites. Hence, in this study, the electrical conductivity percolation threshold of CNT/epoxy nanocomposites is governed by the length of the CNTs and not by the intrinsic electrical properties of the CNTs. However, xCNT/epoxy nanocomposites showed a decrease in electrical conductivity compared to sCNT/epoxy systems. This reduction in ultimate electrical conductivity is due to the presence of local defects and/or presence of non-crystalline carbon,45 which was also confirmed by TGA and Raman spectroscopy. Severe tip-sonication produced local defects or in other words, different chemically active surfaces.45 This lowered the intrinsic ability of xCNTs to conduct electricity efficiently compared to pristine sCNTs.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The effect of shortening multi-walled carbon nanotubes of mCNTs by ultrasonication on the electrical properties of CNT/epoxy nanocomposites was studied. TGA and Raman spectroscopy confirmed significant damage in xCNTs compared to sCNTs, while xCNTs obtained had lengths similar to those of pristine as sCNTs. High-resolution electron microscopy showed that most of the CNTs were well dispersed in the epoxy matrix. Results showed that the percolation threshold for electrical conduction of CNT/epoxy nanocomposites was solely dependant on nanotube length, while ultimate electrical conductivities of the nanocomposites was also dependant on the intrinsic electrical conductivity of the CNTs. Tip-sonication is an effective way to produce shortened CNTs. The use of such shortened CNTs can lead to potential processing advantages of such nanocomposites. However, the damage introduced into the nanotubes by sonication leads to a reduction in ultimate electrical conductivity of their respective epoxy nanocomposites.
